body: [GitMate.io](https://gitmate.io) thinks the contributor most likely able to help you is @nicoddemus.

Thanks @trrichard for the report!

I simplified the test a bit:

```python
import sys
import pytest

@pytest.fixture()
def fix(capfd):
    yield
    out, err = capfd.readouterr()
    assert out == 'lolcatz\n'
    assert err == 'err'

def test_a(fix):
    print("lolcatz")
    sys.stderr.write("err")
```

I confirm that this fails in pytest >=3.3 and works on 3.2.5.

I lean towards it being related to this but I'm just now looking at the code

https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/2709

A quick bisect run shows you are right:

```
9919269ed048b6e9147ee3301532e3591b9a112b is the first bad commit
commit 9919269ed048b6e9147ee3301532e3591b9a112b
Author: Bruno Oliveira <nicoddemus@gmail.com>
Date:   Tue Sep 26 02:34:41 2017 -0300

    Allow to use capsys and capfd in other fixtures

    Fix #2709

:040000 040000 004bc037efc094f23211836b45a0c908944c0e5f 4239d2322f4631055d5a64c5178c5d277c831370 M      _pytest
:040000 040000 d900a2d158ea9a69c319ece6ca72db5913e93d7e 7b88a85bb535d2d562a5e6030ba0bfd856dc03c6 M      changelog
:040000 040000 3aa3d4630888de1ce3b6f51d16c0c5639622fcf6 66399dcb8b52ab95ecca77bdd9d7ebf1963f8e18 M      testing
bisect run success
```

@nicoddemus I'm looking at the code for this and for the previous change and I'm not clear on what the behavior of this *should* be.

Is the expectation that each call to .readouterr() clears the output buffer? Tests like the one here: https://github.com/nicoddemus/pytest/commit/9919269ed048b6e9147ee3301532e3591b9a112b#diff-6221f80f4e6d91715381f8d4229b645cR520 Seem to indicate that.

Similarly how should the capture behave when -s is present on the command line? Does the output go to both places (both the fixture and the output) or just one?

Let me know what you think. I still haven't figured out what actually broke yet, so any insight into that would be appreciated.

issue.title: Fix Capfd From Fixtures After Test Teardown

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

body:
@trrichard Thanks for finding this bug. I am facing the same issue, but removing activate_fixture(item) from teardown does not work for me. I get an error message:

> test.logFile.write(capfd.readouterr().out)
> E       AttributeError: 'tuple' object has no attribute 'out'

Do you see the same issue? Thanks.
There's #3066 open with a possible fix, but it brakes tests. Btw sorry @trrichard for not looking into it yet, but it is in my todo list.

issue.title: Fixtures during teardown can use capsys and capfd to get output from tests

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
The problem is that the fixtures didn't live up to the promise to properly accumulate output between setup/call/teardown. This works in `3.2` because we didn't allow to access the fixture during setup/teardown from the first place, so it didn't need to accumulate any buffer.

Follow up to #3066, fixes #3033.
